   hypoxemic event in this patient is broad and includes both primary
   pulmonary and cardiac processes. Given the patient's worsening
   systolic/diastolic CHF, particularly in the context of an NSTEMI one
   month ago, flash pulmonary edema is the most likely cause of her
   current clinical picture. Her CXR findings and BNP of 30,000 (baseline
   10,000) support this diagnosis, as does her blood gas, which suggests
   metabolic alkalosis [**3-12**] intravascular volume contraction in the setting
   of CHF. She has had several recent admissions for CHF exacerbations,
   therefore this admission may represent a more severe presentation of a
   recurrent problem.
   It also is possible, given the patient's recent MI, that she developed
   an arrhythmia overnight that precipitated a syncopal event and her
   subsequent hypoxemia (via hypoperfusion alone, or via an aspiration
   event), or that she had another MI. No EKG changes. Her troponin was
   slightly elevated at 0.04, but this might be [**3-12**] chronic renal
   insufficiency vs demand ischemia vs volume-related myocardial stretch,
   and her CK was reassuringly normal at 40.
   With respect to a primary pulmonary process: infection and/or mucous
   plugging leading to shunt physiology are two possible diagnoses that
   could cause this clinical picture in isolation or superimposed on a CHF
   exacerbation. New superior LLL opacification on CXR suggests infection;
   however, the patient is afebrile, HD stable, with a normal white count
   (though a left shift). An acute bronchitis superimposed on COPD also
   could cause this clinical picture; the patient has some evidence of
   obstruction on flow-volume loop, as well as slightly flattened
   diaphragms on CXR, but she does not carry an official diagnosis of COPD
   (per OMR and daughter) and has no exam findings (productive cough,
   wheezing) to support this dx. An aspiration event affecting only the
   superior segment of the L lower lobe would be unusual. There is no
   evidence of PTX on CXR. And if she had a PE severe enough to cause a
   syncopal event, we would expect persistent hemodynamic instability,
   which we do not see here.
   Of all these possible diagnoses, flash pulmonary edema and mucous
   plugging are the two most likely to be rapidly reversible, resulting in
   the improved respiratory status demonstrated by this patient upon
   arrival to the floor (i.e. vent settings compatible with extubation).
